utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Completely empty box. If you’d like to examine it?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Mm-hmm. Yep. I see nothing in this box but a wasted childhood.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Little snarky there, cello lessons. And we have this completely ordinary cylinder. If you’d like to examine it?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Ordinary, yet I sense it is dripping with magical potential.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, dear Lord. A man pops out for a moment to evacuate his bowels and catch up on the adventures of the Caped Crusader, only to emerge and discover his apartment has been transformed into a cabaret.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, he’s just practising for his cousin’s birthday party.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: As I was saying, empty box, empty cylinder, and, ooh, voila.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m telling you, dude, there’s a seat on the Hogwarts Express with your name on it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is how you’re going to entertain your little cousin and his friends? By lying to them?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How is this lying?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: A magic show is an inherently deceitful proposition. This is an ordinary top hat. You’ve chosen that card freely. I do not have a set of lock picks lodged in my keister.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Can’t you just enjoy the wonder, Sheldon? Why must you peek behind the curtain? Or up the butt?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If we poison the critical thinking faculties of children by telling them that rabbits come out of hats, then we create adults who believe in astrology and homeopathy and that Ryan Reynolds was a better choice for Green Lantern than lovable rogue Nathan Fillion.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sheldon, he’s just gonna do a few magic tricks for some kids. I really don’t think they’re gonna end up liking the Green Lantern movie.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t be so hard on him. It’s natural to be a little cranky when you have a quarter in your ear!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Coins lodged in body parts is not a source of amusement. When I was five, Billy Sparks put a Mexican peso up my nose.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: How is that not amusing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s still there. Takes me 45 minutes to get through airport security.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Look, I made Sheldon disappear. Ta-da.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Next time, you should open with that.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ooh, look who’s out on a date. Pasadena’s favourite power couple, Shamy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And that is the answer to the question, what is wrong with eating at The Cheesecake Factory?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, are we celebrating anything special tonight?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh, yes. Our relationship agreement specifies that the second Thursday of every month, or the third Thursday in a month with five Thursdays, is date night.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That is so hot.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right, without objection, the minutes of the previous date are considered read and agreed to. Any new business?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: How was your day?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Superb. This morning I made a palindrome with my Alpha-Bits. Nice hat, Bob Tahecin.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sounds like you hit the ground running. I have a bit of good news myself. My most recent paper on how a cooperative long-term potentiation can map memory sequences in dendritic branches made the cover of Neuron.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ooh! Speaking of good news, somebody just hit 100 Twitter followers.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That’s nice. Anyway, I’ve been dreaming of this day for a long time.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, me, too. Triple digits, I’m not gonna lie, feels pretty good.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, I’m the sole author on a paper being published in a distinguished journal that may change the course of my field.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Mm-hmm. Mm-hmm. Ooh, 101! Air’s getting a bit thin up here.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, are we ready to order?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Give me a minute. I’m gonna go wash up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, that’s odd. We both washed up when we came in. It’s probably a euphemism for urination.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, what is wrong with you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not much. Although, I can be faulted for being overly fond of koala bears. I don’t know what it is, when they smart munching on eucalyptus, I just melt inside.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, Amy just told you some exciting news, and you acted like it was no big deal.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I see why you’re confused. No, her news sounded important, but what you’re forgetting is, it was an achievement in the field of biology. That’s all about yucky, squishy things.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Honey, she’s upset. You’re her boyfriend. You have to at least try to be excited by the things she’s excited by.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What if they simply don’t excite me?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, just smile and think about koalas.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: She’d see right through that. We go to the zoo all the time. She knows my koala face. And for future reference, it’s this.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, you have a lot of magic stuff.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah. I started when I was a teenager. I thought I could show a girl a few tricks and invite her up to my bedroom to see the rest of the act.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Did it work?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ah, let’s just say the only wand that ever saw any action was this one. Oh, look what my mom made us for the act.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Ooh. I like the fabric. Where’d she get it?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, she cut up one of her old bathing suits. She made these two vests and half a dozen napkins.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Wolowitz (off)
utterance.content: Has she tried on the vest yet?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I just gave it to her!

utterance.speaker: Mrs Wolowitz (off)
utterance.content: I hope it fits, she has a tricky figure! She’s short and stacked, like me!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: She’s not stacked like you, Ma! She never steps on hers!

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Listen, Howie, maybe I’m not the best choice to be a magician’s assistant.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You’ll do fine. Hand me those rings? See? You nailed it.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You know, i-it’s just that I’m not that comfortable with little kids.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, that’s because you haven’t been around them much. This is good practice. I mean, you are gonna be a mom someday, right?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Mmm, yeah, sure.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh-ho-ho! I haven’t seen this trick in years. It’s called the dove pan. You let everyone see the pan is empty, but there’s a secret compartment in the lid. And then you open it and produce a live… Don’t look in there.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, a little Red Dead Redemption, huh?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How come you’re not doing a mission? You’re just wandering around.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Had a rough night. I thought I’d go for a walk and clear my head.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Some people go outside and do that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s after nine o’clock, at this hour the streets of Pasadena are teeming with drunken sailors and alley cats.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You want to talk about it?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. I think I’ll just go in this saloon and drink my troubles away.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know digital alcohol is never a solution. What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hard as this may be to believe, it’s possible that I’m not boyfriend material.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Glad I was sitting down for that. Did you and Amy get in a fight?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy had a fight. I was being perfectly reasonable. I’m gonna have a whiskey. Do you want anything?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, I can’t. I’m playing Grand Theft Auto later. Look, I’m no expert in women.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ll say.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s not necessary when someone’s trying to help you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry. It’s the alcohol talking. Go on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sometimes with women you want to listen to what upsets them and then show them that you can grow and change.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nuts to that. What else you got?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know what to tell you. Buy her something.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How does that work?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, you skip over any attempt to repair your emotional connection and you win back her affection with an empty financial gesture.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, that approach has Sheldon Cooper written all over it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Glad I could help.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It’s appreciated. And if you ever manage to find a woman again, I’ll be glad to return the favour.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And now, all the rings are magically linked together. My fiancee’s wearing a magic ring, too. It made all my money disappear.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, ah, right. And now, the great Howdini’s next miraculous illusion.

utterance.speaker: Child
utterance.content: When are we gonna have cake?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: After you’ve been thoroughly amazed.

utterance.speaker: Child
utterance.content: But we want cake now.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, you’re not getting cake right now, capisce?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay. Okay. Now, my lovely assistant is going to bring me an ordinary pitcher of milk.

utterance.speaker: Second child
utterance.content: I know how you do that trick.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Do you know how to pipe down?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, we’re going to roll up this newspaper.

utterance.speaker: Second child
utterance.content: It’s a fake pitcher.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You got wax in your ears? The man said it’s an ordinary pitcher. Howdini.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, we’re going to stick this in here and then I’m going to pour in the milk. I hope this works, because I didn’t bring a change of pants.

utterance.speaker: Second child
utterance.content: Look, I Googled it. It’s a fake pitcher.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: That’s it. No cake for you. Anyone else want to join the No Cake Club?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: She’s just kidding, boys and girls. Everyone gets cake.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Not him.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Just give me the pitcher. Behold! Wrong pitcher.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I told you I’m not good with kids.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes, you did. Oh, I think my crotch is starting to curdle.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: The thing is, my mother worked full-time. I had to take care of my brothers and sisters.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, so?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Ugh, it was horrible. With their snotty noses and their poopy diapers and their little shrieky voices, always complaining. I don’t want to get dressed. Joey keeps spitting in my mouth. This isn’t the way Mom makes waffles. Well, okay, put your hand in here. Let’s see how you like this waffle!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All right, settle down. Red light. Red light, red light! Okay, we’re fine.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I know it makes me sound like a bad person, but I just don’t like children.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, no, we all got that. But don’t you think it’ll be different when the child is ours?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Right, when it’s our kid that’s ruined my body and kept me up all night and I’ve got no career and no future and nothing to be happy about for the next 20 years, sure, that’ll be completely different.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t think there’s anything in this jewellery store that Amy would appreciate more than the humidifier we were just looking at at Sears.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, my God, now I know what I sound like to you when I say stupid stuff.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ooh, a pocket watch.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, I don’t think Amy wants a pocket watch.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, but maybe she wants a man with a pocket watch.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Still saying stupid stuff. Ooh, does she like bracelets?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, she’s very fond of her silver one that says allergic to penicillin. Maybe they have a dressier version of that?

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Well, how are we doing this afternoon? Are we looking for anything special? Perhaps a ring for the lady?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Trust me, we are not a couple.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me. I don’t see why you get to snort derisively and point that out. You’d be lucky to land a fella like me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Fine, go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Trust me, we are not a couple.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: My apologies. How can I help you today?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: He’s in trouble with his girlfriend and needs to buy her a present.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Great, trouble with girlfriends is what’s putting my daughter through USC.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ooh, are these real diamonds?

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Yes. Channel set baguettes, 20 points total weight.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Remarkable. Diamonds, crystallized carbon. Every day, people go to the grocery store and come home with sacks full of carbon in the form of charcoal briquettes that they toss in their barbeques and set on fire. But just because you’ve got some carbon with the atoms stacked neatly, you expect me to plunk down thousands of dollars.

utterance.speaker: Assistant
utterance.content: Actually, that’s only 750. Everything’s on sale.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really. Talk to me about that pocket watch.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m still trying to wrap my mind around it. I always thought I’d be a dad someday.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, me, too. You’re so caring. I’ve often pictured you guiding a young boy into manhood.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There you go, Howard. Sounds like Raj’ll have your babies, problem solved.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, just because a man shows caring for another man doesn’t mean he’s displaying the love that dare not speak its name. Did she definitely say she didn’t want kids?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, she doesn’t like them. And from what I saw, the feeling was mutual.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you gonna do?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know. I can’t see a life where I don’t have kids. I mean, people have kids. I mean, even Donkey Kong had Donkey Kong Jr. So he could teach someone how to kidnap princesses and throw barrels at Italian plumbers.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, there’s no guarantee even if you have kids that you’re going to like them.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Wow, that’s rough. Where’d you get that?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s right off the dust jacket of my mom’s last book.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Maybe me and Bernadette aren’t right for each other.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Look, Howard, I’d say there’s a lot of fish in the sea, but I watched you dangle your hook in the water for years. Do not throw her back.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t want to, but this is kind of a deal breaker.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What’s your mom going to say if you call off the wedding?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Huh, it’ll kill her. On the other hand, if I don’t give her grandchildren, that’ll kill her, too. So, either way, on the Mom front, I’m golden.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What time did you tell Amy to be here?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Eight o’clock. Sheldon, that pocket watch is ridiculous.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nonsense. I look like a train conductor. Under what pretext did you lure her here?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I said, hey, want to come over and hang out?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Good, good, if you had said something clever, she might’ve gotten suspicious.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: What’s he doing here?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, he wants to talk to you.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Well, I don’t want to talk to him. And I’m pretty disappointed in you, too. Although we both know that won’t last.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sheldon, you’re up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Thank you. Amy, I’d like to apologize. Your accomplishment was impressive. And I’m proud of you.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: We both know that’s your koala face.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I told you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, look, he bought you this.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Jewellery? Seriously? Sheldon, you are the most shallow, self-centred person I have ever met. Do you really think another transparently manip..oh! It’s a tiara! A tiara! I have a tiara! Put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me, put it on me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You look beautiful.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Of course I do, I’m a princess, and this is my tiara!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re right, the tiara was too much.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Wolowitz (off)
utterance.content: Howard! Bernadette’s… Oh, she slipped right by me.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Here’s your vest back.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You should keep it. You could wear it again sometime.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Where?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know, hunting?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Wolowitz (off)
utterance.content: Don’t forget to talk to her about this mishegas where I don’t get grandkids!

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Don’t worry, Ma. I will, as soon as I can figure out a way to bring up such a sensitive issue!

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I guess you talked to your mom, huh?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I was upset. My mom can be a pretty good shoulder to cry on, if the smell of Bengay doesn’t burn your eyes.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Look, it’s obvious having kids is really important to you, and I think I came up with a solution.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really? That’s great. What?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Well, seeing as how I make way more money than you anyway, what if I work and you stay home with the kids?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Me?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yeah. You know, you’ll watch Barney and pull Cheerios out of their noses and go on play dates, and I’ll work and have conversations with people my own age and enjoy my life.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yay, so we’re good.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, we’re good.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You know, I don’t know if this counted as a fight, but how about some make-up sex?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I would love that. But what is that behind your ear? Oh, look, it’s a condom.
